title: Rugby union’s very future is at stake for wounded Wallabies ahead of World Cup quarter-final with England
text:
If you thought Saturday’s World Cup quarter-final was fateful for England, then just imagine what it could yet portend for the future of rugby union in Australia. At a time when the Wallabies have won just 10 of 22 games in two years, when the governing body has been lacerated for its exiling of Israel Folau, and when union has grown marginalised in its traditional heartlands by rival codes, it is no exaggeration to argue that for the green-and-gold, the survival of the sport itself is at stake.

“I’ll not forget the time Eddie Jones was down here in 2016 with the England tour,” says Simon Poidevin, the star flanker who lifted the Webb Ellis Cup for Australia in 1991, and who played alongside...
description: If you thought Saturday’s World Cup quarter-final was fateful for England, then just imagine what it could yet portend for the future of rugby union in Australia.
